key_issues: The petitioner is seeking rectification of the Register of Trade Marks by removal of Registration No. 4842932 dated 5th July 2021, which registered the word mark “PIZZA GALLERIA” in favor of Respondent 1 under Class 30.
The petitioner is challenging the right of Respondent 1 to use the “PIZZA GALLERIA” mark in the city of Rewari, but not in any other part of the country.
The petitioner and Respondent 1 are both running eating outlets under the name “PIZZA GALLERIA”, with the petitioner's outlets situated in Rewari and Respondent 1's outlets situated outside Rewari.
The case involves an application made under Section 57 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, for rectification of the Register of Trade Marks.

The classification of goods and services is relevant, as the registration of the “PIZZA GALLERIA” mark is under Class 30, which covers “flour and preparations made from cereals; bread, pizza, pastry and confectionery”.

The Court has the power to cancel or vary the registration of a trade mark under Section 57 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, on the grounds of contravention or failure to observe a condition entered on the register.
The Respondent 1 is unwilling to surrender the registration of the “PIZZA GALLERIA” mark, despite the petitioner's limited challenge to its use in Rewari.
The petitioner's claim is based on the grounds that the registration of the “PIZZA GALLERIA” mark by Respondent 1 is wrongful and should be removed from the register.
The Court must determine whether the petitioner has a legitimate grievance and whether the registration of the “PIZZA GALLERIA” mark by Respondent 1 should be rectified.
The case highlights the issue of territoriality in trade mark law, where the petitioner is only challenging the use of the mark in a specific geographic area, rather than nationwide.
metadata.decision_summary:
**Case Summary: Raj Kumar Sharma vs. Sandeep Kumar & Anr.**

**Background:**
The case involves a dispute over the use of the trade mark "PIZZA GALLERIA" between two parties, Raj Kumar Sharma (the petitioner) and Sandeep Kumar (Respondent 1). Both parties are running eating outlets under the same name, with the petitioner's outlets located in Rewari and Respondent 1's outlets situated outside Rewari.

**Legal Issues:**
The petitioner has filed a petition under Section 57 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, seeking rectification of the Register of Trade Marks by removing the registration of the word mark "PIZZA GALLERIA" (Registration No. 4842932) in favor of Respondent 1 under Class 30 of the Alphabetical Index of classification of goods. The petitioner contests Respondent 1's right to use the mark in Rewari, but not in other parts of the country.

**Arguments:**

* The petitioner's counsel, Mr. Nikhil Sonker, argued that the petitioner does not object to Respondent 1 using the "PIZZA GALLERIA" mark outside Rewari, but contests the right to use it in Rewari.
* Respondent 1's counsel, Ms. Garima Sachdeva, argued that her client is unwilling to surrender the Rewari market and had previously refused to accept a disclaimer restricting the use of the mark in Rewari.

**Court Findings:**
The Hon'ble Mr. Justice C. Hari Shankar noted that the petitioner has no objection to Respondent 1 using the "PIZZA GALLERIA" mark outside Rewari, which raises questions about the necessity of the court's involvement in the dispute. The judge also observed that the parties are both using the same mark, with the petitioner's outlets located in Rewari and Respondent 1's outlets located outside Rewari.

**Decision:**
Although the judgment does not explicitly state the decision, it can be inferred that the court is likely to exercise its discretion under Section 57 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, to rectify the register by removing the registration of the "PIZZA GALLERIA" mark in favor of Respondent 1, but only to the extent of restricting its use in Rewari. Alternatively, the court may order the parties to coexist, with the petitioner's outlets in Rewari and Respondent 1's outlets outside Rewari, or explore other possible solutions, such as a disclaimer or a geographical restriction on the use of the mark.

**Conclusion:**
The case highlights the complexities of trade mark disputes, particularly when parties are using the same mark in different geographical locations. The court's decision will likely depend on the specific circumstances of the case, including the parties' intentions, the scope of their businesses, and the potential impact on consumers. Ultimately, the court's goal will be to balance the competing interests of the parties and ensure that the use of the "PIZZA GALLERIA" mark does not cause confusion or harm to consumers in Rewari or elsewhere.

challenge in the present petition, the petitioner has stated that the

impugned mark infracted Section 11(1) of the Trademarks Act.  As 
such, it cannot be said that the submission of Mr. Sonker is entirely 
divorced from the pleadings.   
 
23. 
Section 57(2) of the Trademarks Act permits the making of an 
application for making, expunging or varying any entry in the Trade 
Marks Register, where the applicant alleges that (i) the entry is made 
without sufficient cause or (ii) is wrongly remaining on the register or 
(iii) suffers from any error or defect.  Mr. Sonker submits that 
circumstance (ii) applies to the present case.  As such, he submits, in 
view of Section 11(1)(b) of the Trade Marks Act, the impugned

petition, to the use, by the defendant, of the impugned “PIZZA 
GALLERIA” mark in the city of Rewari, I direct the rectification of 
Registration No. 4842932 granted to Respondent 1 for the word mark 
“PIZZA GALLERIA” on 5th July 2021 to be rectified by inserting, 
therein, a disclaimer disallowing the use of the said mark, by the 
defendant, in the city of Rewari, while retaining the right of the 
defendant to use the mark elsewhere in the country.   
 
25. 
This petition stands disposed of in the aforesaid terms.  
 
A Postscript 
 
26. 
A somewhat quixotic statutory position has come to my notice 
while correcting this judgement.  Earlier, classification of goods and 
services, for the purposes of registration of trade marks, was contained 
in the Fourth Schedule to the Trade Marks Rules, 2002 (“the 2002 TM 
Rules”).  The 2002 TM Rules were, subsequently, superseded by the 
Trade Marks Rules, 2017 (“the 2017 TM Rules”).  Rule 185 of the 
2017 TM Rules repeals the 2002 Rules “without prejudice to anything 
done under such rules before the coming into force of” the 2017 TM 
Rules.  New Registrations have, therefore, to be as per the 2017 TM 
Rules, and cannot abide by the 2002 TM Rules.  I am informed, 
however, that, even as on date, a registrant seeking to register a trade 
mark has to classify the mark as per the 2002 TM Rules.  This appears 
to be erroneous, in view of Rule 185 of the 2017 TM Rules supra.

27. 
That apart, Section 7(1) of the Trade Marks Act requires the 
Registrar of Trade Marks to classify goods and services, as far as may 
be, in accordance with the International classification of goods and 
services (the NICE Classification) for the purposes of registration of 
trade marks.  Section 7(2) makes the decision of any question as to the 
class within which any goods or services falls, by the Registrar, final.  
Section 8(1) requires the Registrar to publish, in the prescribed 
manner, an alphabetical list of classification of goods and services for 
the purpose of registration of trade marks.  These provisions, 
therefore, require the Registrar to classify the goods or services, for 
the purpose of registration, in accordance with the NICE 
classification, only as far as may be.  Rule 20(1) of the 2017 TM 
Rules, however, departs, somewhat, from Section 7(1) of the TM Act, 
as it makes classification of goods and services, for the purpose of 
registration of trade marks, to be mandatorily “as per current edition 
of „the international Classification of goods and services (NICE 
classification)‟ published by the WIPO.  Thus, where Section 7(1) 
makes the NICE classification applicable for classification of goods 
and services under the TM Act only as far as may be, Rule 20(1) 
makes it mandatory for the classification of goods and services to 
abide by the NICE classification.  There is, therefore, an apparent 
discrepancy between Section 7(1) of the TM Act and Rule 20(1) of the 
TM Rules.  This may need statutory correction. 
 
28. 
The Registrar of Trade Marks is requested to examine this 
aspect.

The case involves a petition by Raj Kumar Sharma (Plaintiff) against Sandeep Kumar and another (Defendants) regarding the registration of the trade mark "PIZZA GALLERIA". The plaintiff seeks rectification of the Register of Trade Marks by removing the registration of "PIZZA GALLERIA" in favor of the first respondent.

The petition is filed under Section 571 of the Trade Marks Act, 1999, and the plaintiff is represented by Mr. Nikhil Sonker, Advocate. The defendants are represented by Ms. Garima Sachdeva, Advocate for R-1, and Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar, CGSC, with other advocates for R-2.

The dispute is restricted to the use of the "PIZZA GALLERIA" mark in the city of Rewari, where both parties have eating outlets under the same name. The plaintiff does not object to the respondent using the mark outside Rewari but seeks to prevent its use within the city.

The court, presided over by Hon'ble Mr. Justice C. Hari Shankar, heard the arguments on January 30, 2023. The judgment is yet to be finalized, but the court seems inclined to question the necessity of the dispute, given the plaintiff's willingness to allow the respondent to use the mark outside Rewari. The case highlights the complexities of trade mark disputes and the need for careful consideration of territorial rights. (Source: Raj Kumar v. Sandeep Kumar & Anr..pdf)

tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Raj Kumar v. Sandeep Kumar & Anr..pdf", the High Court of Delhi is hearing a case between Raj Kumar Sharma (Plaintiff) and Sandeep Kumar & Anr. (Defendants) regarding the "PIZZA GALLERIA" trademark. The dispute arose from a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) allegedly executed on June 9, 2021, allowing the plaintiff to use the mark in Rewari, while the defendant could use it elsewhere. However, the defendant disputes the MoU, claiming it is fabricated.

The plaintiff had applied for registration of a device mark under Class 35 on August 31, 2020, prior to the defendant's application for the "PIZZA GALLERIA" word mark on February 1, 2021. The court must decide whether the defendant's registration can be allowed, considering Section 11(1) of the Trade Marks Act, which deals with relative grounds for refusal of registration due to likelihood of confusion.

The plaintiff argues that the device mark is similar to the "PIZZA GALLERIA" word mark, as it features a pictorial representation of a pizza, and therefore, there is a likelihood of confusion. The court must consider the facts, including the dates of application and the similarity of the marks, to make a decision. The case highlights the importance of trademark law and the need to resolve disputes over intellectual property rights. (Source: Raj Kumar v. Sandeep Kumar & Anr..pdf, pages 1-4)

As there appears to be substance in this contention, it is not 
necessary to examine any of the other contentions urged at the bar by

11. 
Clauses (a) and (b) of Section 11(1) envisage independent 
circumstances in which a trade mark is ineligible for registration.  Of 
these, where the mark for which registration has been applied is 
identical to an earlier trademark, Clause (a) would apply, whereas, 
where the applicant‟s mark is similar to an earlier trademark, Clause 
(b) would apply.  In either case, likelihood of confusion on the part of 
the public must be shown to exist, in order for the later mark to be 
ineligible for registration.

Explanation to the Section.  Clause (a) of the explanation includes,

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
The legal document section from the PDF "Raj Kumar v. Sandeep Kumar & Anr." (Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000647, C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2021) discusses a trademark dispute between Raj Kumar Sharma (plaintiff) and Sandeep Kumar & Anr. (defendants). The plaintiff's device mark features a pictorial depiction of a pizza with the word "Galleria" alongside it, while the defendant's mark is the word "PIZZA GALLERIA". 

The court argues that the two marks are similar, which could lead to confusion among consumers. The plaintiff's counsel, Mr. Nikhil Sonker, points out that the petitioner was referred to as "PIZZA GALLERIA" in invoices, and that the nature of services provided by both parties is identical (restaurant services). The court also notes that the goods and services covered by the marks are allied, relating to food items and retail services.

The court cites relevant case law, including Mex Switchgears Pvt. Ltd. v. Omex Cables Industries and Natures Essence Private Limited v. Protogreen Retail Solutions Private Limited, to support its decision that the marks are similar and could cause confusion. The document is digitally signed by Kamla Rawat on January 31, 2023. The case highlights the importance of trademark similarity and the potential for consumer confusion in the hospitality industry. (Source: Raj Kumar v. Sandeep Kumar & Anr..pdf)

nodes.summary: According to page 6 of the PDF "40. Raj Kumar v. Sandeep Kumar & Anr..pdf", the court discusses the similarity between the petitioner's device mark and the respondent's "PIZZA GALLERIA" word mark. The court concludes that the marks can be regarded as "similar" due to the likelihood of confusion. The petitioner's mark features a pictorial depiction of a pizza with the word "Galleria" alongside it, while the respondent's mark is "PIZZA GALLERIA", where "Galleria" is the dominant part. The court references Section 2(1)(h) of the Trade Marks Act, which states that a mark is deceptively similar if it resembles another mark closely enough to deceive or cause confusion. The case is C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2021, with Neutral Citation Number 2023/DHC/000647. The court's decision was signed on January 31, 2023.

13. 
Can, then, the 
 device mark of the petitioner, and the 
“PIZZA GALLERIA” word mark of the respondent, be regarded as 
“similar”, as would result in a likelihood of confusion?   
 
14. 
After some cogitation, I feel the answer has to be in the 
affirmative. 
 
15. 
The expression “similar” is not defined in the Trade Marks Act.  
Section 2(1)(h), however, declares, in an admirably circular fashion, 
that “a mark shall be deemed to be deceptively similar to another mark 
if it so nearly resembles the other mark as to be likely to deceive or 
cause confusion”.   Thus, Section 2(1)(h) embraces, within the broad 
parentheses of “deceptive similarity”, both “confusing” and 
“deceptive” similarity.  Likelihood of deception or confusion, in any 
event, remains the pervading mantra. 
 
16. 
The petitioner‟s 
 mark contains a pictorial depiction 
of a pizza, with the word “Galleria” alongside it.  A mental connect 
beween the pizza and “Galleria” is, however, immediately made by an 
average consumer who sees the mark.  The impugned mark of the 
respondent is “PIZZA GALLERIA”.  In the mark “PIZZA 
GALLERIA”, there can be no manner of doubt that “Galleria” is the 
dominant part, as “pizza” is publici juris, used by nearly every eatery 
which specializes in pizzas.  “Galleria” may be a term more often

tree_structure.title: Court Decision
tree_structure.summary:
According to the PDF document "Raj Kumar v. Sandeep Kumar & Anr..pdf", a court decision was made in the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi, with the Neutral Citation Number: 2023/DHC/000647 and C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2021. The plaintiff, Raj Kumar Sharma, was represented by Mr. Nikhil Sonker, while the defendants, Sandeep Kumar and Anr., were represented by Ms. Garima Sachdeva and Mr. Harish Vaidyanathan Shankar.

The court decision, dated January 30, 2023, ruled that the use of the "PIZZA GALLERIA" mark by the defendant in the city of Rewari was violative of Section 11(1)(b) of the Trademarks Act. As a result, the court directed the rectification of Registration No. 4842932 by inserting a disclaimer disallowing the use of the mark in Rewari, while retaining the defendant's right to use it elsewhere in the country.

The court also noted a discrepancy between Section 7(1) of the Trademarks Act and Rule 20(1) of the Trademarks Rules, 2017, regarding the classification of goods and services for registration purposes. The Registrar of Trade Marks was requested to examine this aspect. The petition was disposed of in the aforementioned terms, with the decision digitally signed by Kamla Rawat on January 31, 2023. (Source: Raj Kumar v. Sandeep Kumar & Anr..pdf, Pages 1-11)

                                                        Page 10 of 11  
 
   
 
5th July 2021 is violative of Section 11(1)(b) of the Trademarks Act, 
the said word mark is liable to be removed from the register.  
However, as Mr Sonker has restricted his challenge, in the present 
petition, to the use, by the defendant, of the impugned “PIZZA 
GALLERIA” mark in the city of Rewari, I direct the rectification of 
Registration No. 4842932 granted to Respondent 1 for the word mark 
“PIZZA GALLERIA” on 5th July 2021 to be rectified by inserting, 
therein, a disclaimer disallowing the use of the said mark, by the 
defendant, in the city of Rewari, while retaining the right of the 
defendant to use the mark elsewhere in the country.   
 
25. 
This petition stands disposed of in the aforesaid terms.  
 
A Postscript 
 
26. 
A somewhat quixotic statutory position has come to my notice 
while correcting this judgement.  Earlier, classification of goods and 
services, for the purposes of registration of trade marks, was contained 
in the Fourth Schedule to the Trade Marks Rules, 2002 (“the 2002 TM 
Rules”).  The 2002 TM Rules were, subsequently, superseded by the 
Trade Marks Rules, 2017 (“the 2017 TM Rules”).  Rule 185 of the 
2017 TM Rules repeals the 2002 Rules “without prejudice to anything 
done under such rules before the coming into force of” the 2017 TM 
Rules.  New Registrations have, therefore, to be as per the 2017 TM 
Rules, and cannot abide by the 2002 TM Rules.  I am informed, 
however, that, even as on date, a registrant seeking to register a trade 
mark has to classify the mark as per the 2002 TM Rules.  This appears 
to be erroneous, in view of Rule 185 of the 2017 TM Rules supra.

Section 7(1) requires classification "as far as may be" in accordance with the International Classification of goods and services (NICE Classification), while Rule 20(1) makes it mandatory to follow the NICE classification. The court notes that this discrepancy may need statutory correction. The Registrar of Trade Marks is requested to examine this aspect. The judgment was made by C. Hari Shankar, J on January 30, 2023. Neutral Citation Number : 2023/DHC/000647 
 C.O. (COMM.IPD-TM) 39/2021 
                                                        Page 11 of 11  
 
   
 
27. 
That apart, Section 7(1) of the Trade Marks Act requires the 
Registrar of Trade Marks to classify goods and services, as far as may 
be, in accordance with the International classification of goods and 
services (the NICE Classification) for the purposes of registration of 
trade marks.  Section 7(2) makes the decision of any question as to the 
class within which any goods or services falls, by the Registrar, final.  
Section 8(1) requires the Registrar to publish, in the prescribed 
manner, an alphabetical list of classification of goods and services for 
the purpose of registration of trade marks.  These provisions, 
therefore, require the Registrar to classify the goods or services, for 
the purpose of registration, in accordance with the NICE 
classification, only as far as may be.  Rule 20(1) of the 2017 TM 
Rules, however, departs, somewhat, from Section 7(1) of the TM Act, 
as it makes classification of goods and services, for the purpose of 
registration of trade marks, to be mandatorily “as per current edition 
of „the international Classification of goods and services (NICE 
classification)‟ published by the WIPO.  Thus, where Section 7(1) 
makes the NICE classification applicable for classification of goods 
and services under the TM Act only as far as may be, Rule 20(1) 
makes it mandatory for the classification of goods and services to 
abide by the NICE classification.  There is, therefore, an apparent 
discrepancy between Section 7(1) of the TM Act and Rule 20(1) of the 
TM Rules.  This may need statutory correction. 
 
28. 
The Registrar of Trade Marks is requested to examine this 
aspect. 
 
 
C.HARI SHANKAR, J
